mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Port Chicago Explosion -- Munitions Ships

mods:mods.mods:note: Two military (Merchant Marine) munitions ships, the E.A. Bryan (ship) and the Quinalt Victory (ship) explode at Port Chicago (Calif.), killing personnel, destroying ships and pier and damaging local businesses and homes. Damaged structures and hospitalized persons are shown, as well as some Red Cross relief efforts, area residents, repair work on the Southern Pacific station, and a memorial service for merchant seamen killed. [No African American servicemen are pictured, but, according to the website of the Dept. of the Navy’s Naval Historical Center (as of July 2003) : "Of the 320 men killed in the explosion, 202 were the African-American enlisted men who were assigned the dangerous duty of loading the ships. The explosion at Port Chicago accounted for fifteen percent of all African-American casualties of World War II." Later, many African American survivors were court martialed for refusal to return to munitions loading duty.] [Only selected images have been digitized.]

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: COFO (Council of Federated Organizations?) Sit-in -- US Attorney's Office

mods:mods.mods:note: Several protesters (including African Americans) sitting on the floor of the US Attorney's office. Various views of Cecil Poole standing and surrounded by reporters. Men carrying or dragging protesters out of the office and building. Tom Miller speaking into a microphone as Poole looks on. Poole standing in an elevator with protesters (social protests, civil rights). [Only selected images have been digitized.]

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: White Citizens' Council Meeting -- CORE and SLATE Protest

mods:mods.mods:note: CORE (Congress of Racial Equality) and SLATE picket outside Masonic Auditorium. Protestors carry signs. Protestors jeer at people who attended meeting as they leave building's garage. Robert Gill (local leader of Council) is interviewed by a reporter (social protests, race relations, civil rights). [Contact prints available, shelved under BANC PIC 1959.010--PIC Part 3 : 10-28-64.6 -- ] [Only selected images have been digitized.]

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Press Conference -- Boxer Joe Louis -- Booker T. Washington Hotel

mods:mods.mods:note: Joe Louis, former heavyweight champion boxer, speaks to Jane [his wife?] during press conference. Speaks to reporters. mods:titleInfo.mods:title: African Americans Pickets -- Woolworths and Kress Store -- Market Street

mods:mods.mods:note: Terry Francois, attorney and local head of National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) leads picket line in front of Woolworths. Signs read "Negroes are treated as tresspassers in Woolworths Dixie stores" and "Stop Jailing Negro college kids for trying to trade with Kress" (race relations, social protest)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Local NAACP President Starts Boycott of Kress and Woolworths (stores)

mods:mods.mods:note: President of San Francisco branch of National Association for Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) Terry Francois and college student Thomas Gaither stand together. They hold the NAACP Organization and Conference Manual, West Coast Region. Francois will speak at a local NAACP meeting in Longshoremens' Hall to start boycott of Kress and Woolworths stores. (race relations? civil rights?) [Only selected images have been digitized.]

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Willie Mays Beef -- Difficulty Buying House

mods:mods.mods:note: Baseball player Willie Mays being interviewed, and view of house he was prevented from buying because of race (race relations, African Americans, civil rights). Television cameras and interview with Walter A. Genesdiloff [sic], builder of the house in dispute. Also present is Edward Howden (director of Council for Civic Unity). Taken at 266(?) Magellan Ave. [Only selected images have been digitized.]

mods:mods.mods:note: Rabbi Alvin Fine, Chairman William Chester, United States attorney Cecil Poole, and Leonard Farmer talk to the huge crowd filling the streets in front of the Post Office building about the bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Alabama which resulted in the deaths of four young girls (hate crimes, civil rights). mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Ethnically Mixed Congregation -- Westminster Presbyterian Church

mods:mods.mods:note: Photographs of church service uniting white congregation from Westminster Church and African American congregation from Hope Church [the unification of the two churches resulted from changing population patterns in the twelve block area surrounding the churches, including the decline in white population and the resulting decline in Westminster Church membership, and the increase in African American population]. New church Pastor Wesley L. Hawes sings from pulpit, as visiting pastors stand and sing in line to his left. Hampton B. Hawes of Louisiana, father of Wesley Hawes, speaks to congregation. Visiting pastors stand in line and sing, with two African American pastors standing before altar to rear and above. Hampton Hawes speaks to congregation about issue of church population. View of congregation in pews (race relations). [Only selected images have been digitized.]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Port Chicago Explosion -- Munitions Ships
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two military (Merchant Marine) munitions ships, the E.A. Bryan (ship) and the Quinalt Victory (ship) explode at Port Chicago (Calif.), killing personnel, destroying ships and pier and damaging local businesses and homes. Damaged structures and hospitalized persons are shown, as well as some Red Cross relief efforts, area residents, repair work on the Southern Pacific station, and a memorial service for merchant seamen killed. [No African American servicemen are pictured, but, according to the website of the Dept. of the Navy’s Naval Historical Center (as of July 2003) : "Of the 320 men killed in the explosion, 202 were the African-American enlisted men who were assigned the dangerous duty of loading the ships. The explosion at Port Chicago accounted for fifteen percent of all African-American casualties of World War II." Later, many African American survivors were court martialed for refusal to return to munitions loading duty.] [Only selected images have been digitized.]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Willie Mays Beef -- Difficulty Buying House
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Baseball player Willie Mays being interviewed, and view of house he was prevented from buying because of race (race relations, African Americans, civil rights). Taken at 2251 Moraga Street and 175 Miraloma Drive. Willie Mays signing home sale agreement with wife, attorney Terry A. Francois, and owner Walter A. Gnesdiloff [sic]. Taken at 2251 Moraga Street. Television cameras and interview with Walter A. Genesdiloff [sic], builder of the house in dispute. Also present is Edward Howden (director of Council for Civic Unity). Taken at 266(?) Magellan Ave. [Only selected images have been digitized.]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ethnically Mixed Congregation -- Westminster Presbyterian Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photographs of church service uniting white congregation from Westminster Church and African American congregation from Hope Church [the unification of the two churches resulted from changing population patterns in the twelve block area surrounding the churches, including the decline in white population and the resulting decline in Westminster Church membership, and the increase in African American population]. New church Pastor Wesley L. Hawes sings from pulpit, as visiting pastors stand and sing in line to his left. Hampton B. Hawes of Louisiana, father of Wesley Hawes, speaks to congregation. Visiting pastors stand in line and sing, with two African American pastors standing before altar to rear and above. Hampton Hawes speaks to congregation about issue of church population. View of congregation in pews (race relations). [Only selected images have been digitized.]
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans--California--San Francisco Bay Area
